subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: But Paul, how are you handling multiple entries in the dictionary? I think you should choose the first entry. See next post. Ted
messageBody:
But Paul, how are you handling multiple entries in the dictionary? I
think you should choose the first entry. See next post.

Ted

On Nov 15, 2007 3:59 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Paige Gabhart wrote:
> >
> >
> > My take is different on this. I agree with Ted in that I believe that
> > Moira's pronunciation is in the minority, but so what? I say jettison
> > the rule and stick with phonemic writing. It causes me no difficulty to
> > read Moira's QS with "It" at the end of words as opposed to "Eat." She
> > can spell it the way she wants, and I can spell it with "Eat." way.
> >
> > I've been reading the QS news with some peculiar spellings such as
> > "jurists" written as "juris" I want to know what's up with that? Is
> > that really in the CMU dictionary or is that some peculiarity of the
> > tranliteration program Paul wrote? The closest dictionary to hand
> > happens to be a Funk & Wagnall's. The pronunciation shows a "t" at the
> > end of the word.
> >
>
> I too find the missing Ts annoying, but that problem results because of
> the CMU dictionary, not my program.
>
> I want the dictionary to be produce words that most readers can readily
> understand, but in order for this to happen, I need users to contribute
> lists of words spelled the correct way. But then, what is the correct
> way? We have not reached consensus on how exactly to spell words in a
> more formal text like a newspaper.
>
> Paul
>
>
